title: Who will develop the CT cruise terminal?
text:
Who will develop the CT cruise terminal? Article By: Megan Ellis Wed, 01 Jul 2015 5:44 PM Share Your Email 
The bid for the development of a cruise terminal in Cape Town has been awarded by the Transnet National Ports Authority (TNPA). 
The status of Preferred Bidder was awarded to V&A Waterfront (Pty) Ltd, TNPA said in a press release. 
To develop the port, the V&A Waterfront is set to invest just under R179-million. 
However, after a period of 10 years, the ownership of the facility will be transferred back to TNPA. 
"The upgraded Cape Town cruise terminal facility to be developed by V&A Waterfront will be a gateway to a unique African experience in cruise tourism," TNPA Chief Executive Richard Vallihu said in a statement. 
"Transnet is excited about playing a role in entrenching Cape Town as a leading destination in Africa and the world," he said. 
"The city will benefit from a world-class facility that will attract greater international cruise liner calls, create jobs and strengthen the tourism offering of not only the Mother City, but South Africa as a whole." 
V&A Waterfront CEO David Green welcomed the bid award. 
"We recognise that cruise liner tourism is one of the fastest growing areas of tourism. Our area of responsibility is that of contributing positively to Cape Town, the Western Cape and South Africa," he said. 
"This award is an opportunity to positively contribute to the economy, job creation and providing a positive experience for all visitors," Green said. 
"The cruise terminal gives us the opportunity to extend a warm welcome to our fair city, and is important due to the first impression it will create of Cape Town." Related Articles
